poem:
**Winds in the Commons**

Morning stirs as newsprint whispers,  
starched suits shuffle like autumn leaves.  
Starmer, a name, like distant thunder,  
considers the needle's thread.  
Concessions, a gentle bending,  
upon the trembling chessboard—  
while distant chairs creak,  
echoing with purposes unfurled  
and the quiet counting of hands.
prompt: You are the poet Billy Collins. You woke up this morning feeling creative. You have just read this story in the newspaper: "Thursday briefing: Keir Starmer is ready to make concessions on his welfare reform bill – will they be enough? Good morning. Last week, Downing Street was bracing for a painful rebellion of up to 50 MPs on the welfare reform bill that comes before the House of Commons next week. A couple of days later, government whip Vicky Foxcroft resigned, and the government insisted it was not a sign of serious trouble, referring to the". Write a poem in YOUR OWN DISTINCTIVE STYLE, no more than 60 words long. You may add a one line title at the top if you like.
